title: 103_hr3349
content:
The "First Lunar Landing Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of coins to celebrate the 25th Anniversary of the first lunar landing. The Secretary of the Treasury is authorized to mint and issue up to 500,000 1-dollar coins commemorating the first lunar landing. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The design must symbolize the lunar landing and include various inscriptions such as "Liberty," "In God We Trust," and "E Pluribus Unum." The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender and selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Administrator of NASA. They will also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The Secretary will obtain silver for coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. Coins may be issued starting January 1, 1994, in uncirculated and proof qualities, from only one Mint facility. Minting under this Act ends on December 31, 1994. The Secretary will sell coins minted under the Act at a price equal to face value plus costs and a $5 surcharge per coin. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a discount reflecting prepayment benefits. The surcharges from the sale of coins minted under this Act will be distributed as follows: 25% to the Ohio Historic Preservation Association for the Neil Armstrong Air and Space Museum, 25% to the Smithsonian Institution for the National Air and Space Museum, and 50% to the Treasury for reducing the national debt. SEC. 8. AUDITS.

Ohio Historic Preservation Association must allow the Comptroller General to examine relevant records related to surcharge expenditures.

SEC. 9. FINANCIAL REQUIREMENT.

The Secretary must ensure that minting coins under this Act will not cost the Federal Government.

SEC. 10. PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 10. PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to minting coins under this Act, except for equal employment opportunity requirements. SEC. 11. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND.

Coins minted under this Act are considered numismatic items under title 31, United States Code.
